response:
[start of motion plan]  
The task is to strangle the neck while grasping the neck.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:  
- Object Properties: The relevant object for the "neck" is assumed to be part of an articulated mannequin or doll, given the visible humanoid robot arm and the typical object shape it would interact with in such a scenario. The neck can be approximated as a cylindrical or slightly tapered rigid segment composed of plastic material, lightweight, and moderately stiff with low compliance. Estimated mass of the neck section is around 0.2 kg. The static friction coefficient between the robot rubberized gripper surfaces and the plastic neck is estimated as 0.5, ensuring sufficient friction for grasping without slipping under moderate force.  
- Environmental Factors: The interaction occurs on a smooth, wooden table with low friction (estimated static friction coefficient about 0.3 between plastic and wood). Gravity acts downward along the vertical axis (+Z in the workspace). The neck joint likely has some hinge or pivot resistance but no drive torque, so it will resist twisting motions without active bending.  
- The relevant object is the neck of a small plastic mannequin, cylindrical and moderately stiff, with a mass of approximately 0.2 kg, and a static friction coefficient of 0.5 in contact with the robot gripper.  
- The surface of interaction is a wooden tabletop with static friction coefficient 0.3 with the mannequin material.  
- Contact Types: The robot will use a firm pinch grasp around the neck, engaging opposing gripper surfaces to create uniform circumferential contact ensuring no slip in the rotational or translational directions. Maintaining full surface contact along the wrist frame X and Y axes is critical for grasp stability.  
- Motion Type: The strangling action resembles a combination of rotational twisting (to tighten) of the neck combined with inward linear forces to squeeze or apply compression. This is primarily a combination of rotation about the wrist Z-axis and linear compression along the wrist X and Y axes.  
- Contact Considerations: To maintain the pinch grasp and prevent slip during twisting, significant normal force along the gripper closing direction (wrist Y axis) is required. Additionally, small positive force along wrist X axis is needed to maintain firm grip and resist any lateral slippage during torque application. The Z axis is used to maintain stable vertical contact without lifting or dropping the neck.  
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts a combination of linear forces and torques: positive linear force along wrist Y axis (grasping inward), small positive linear force along X axis (lateral grip stability), near-zero linear force along Z axis (hold in place vertically), and applies clockwise torque about the Z axis (rotation to strangle/twist). Torques about X and Y axes are negligible as the twisting does not involve tilting motions.  
- Task duration: The task involves a controlled twist and hold, estimated total duration about 5 seconds to ensure secure strangling motion without damage or slip.

Physical Model (if applicable):  
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Neck mass = 0.2 kg; friction coefficient (gripper-neck) = 0.5; friction coefficient (neck-table) = 0.3; gravity acceleration = 9.81 m/s²; estimated torque to twist neck = ~0.5 N-m (small plastic structure resistance).  
- Relevant equations:  
  Force to prevent slip = mass * gravity * friction coefficient;  
  Torque = force * lever arm (approximate neck radius ~0.02 m).  
- Relevant assumptions: The neck radius is about 0.02 m, homogeneous material, twist torque is small, gripper-to-neck friction dominates slip prevention.  
- Computations:  
  Grasping force needed to hold neck against gravity and twisting:  
  F_grasp_min ~ mass * g / friction coefficient = 0.2 * 9.81 / 0.5 ≈ 3.92 N (minimum inward grasp force)  
  To generate twisting torque of 0.5 N-m with lever arm 0.02 m:  
  Required tangential force = torque / lever arm = 0.5 / 0.02 = 25 N  
  Since the twist is from rotation of gripper, inner grasp must resist this, so grasping force is set higher safely, around 25 N.  
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.2 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.5 along the surface:  
  Inward grasp force along Y-axis: ~25 N to resist twisting slip  
  Lateral grip holding force along X-axis: ~5 N to ensure slip prevention during twisting  
  Vertical force along Z-axis: ~0 N (hold in place, gravity balanced by table)  
  Torque about Z-axis: clockwise torque of ~0.5 N-m to twist and strangle the neck  
  Torques about X and Y axes: negligible (no tilt needed)

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:  
Linear X-axis: To stabilize the neck and maintain firm grip preventing lateral slip during twisting, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 5 N on the object.  
Linear Y-axis: To accomplish the strangling by grasping tightly, the robot exerts positive force along the Y-axis with magnitude 25 N (pinch grasp force to resist slipping).  
Linear Z-axis: To maintain position against gravity without lifting or dropping, the robot exerts no linear force along the Z-axis (0 N).  
Angular X-axis: No angular torque is required about the X-axis (0 N-m) as no tilting motion is involved.  
Angular Y-axis: No angular torque is required about the Y-axis (0 N-m) as no tilting motion is involved.  
Angular Z-axis: To accomplish the strangling twist motion, the robot exerts clockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 0.5 N-m.  
Grasping force: Estimated grasping force range is 20 to 30 N to avoid slip and safely apply twist torque; thus 25 N is selected for robust performance.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:  
```python  
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.  
property_description = "A small plastic neck segment from a mannequin with mass 0.2 kg, static friction coefficient 0.5 against rubber gripper surfaces."  
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes  
wrist_motion_description = "Apply pinch grasp force along wrist Y axis, stabilize grip along X axis, maintain no vertical motion, apply twisting clockwise torque about Z axis to strangle neck."  
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes  
wrist_wrench = [5.0, 25.0, 0.0, 0.0, 0.0, -0.5]  
# the grasping force, which must be positive  
grasp_force = 25.0  
# the task duration, which must be positive  
duration = 5.0  
```  

[end of motion plan]

Given the user instruction and an image of the robot workspace, generate a structured physical plan for a robot end-effector interacting with the environment.
The task is to strangle the neck while grasping the neck.

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities. 
Motions can include grasping, lifting, pushing, tapping, sliding, rotating, or any interaction with objects or surfaces.
Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.
Use physical reasoning to complete the following plan in a structured format. Carefully map the required motion in the world to the required motion, forces, and torques at the wrist.

1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
